    Data Download Process

cronus

Source: vignettes/cronus.Rmd
cronus.Rmd

Welcome to cronus!

The prometheus project applies advanced statistical methodology on remote sensing agriculture. It is composed of several R packages, as well as other elements, each one focusing on a different application.

cronus is an R package that focuses on database creation. It can be used to download and process agricultural, environmental and satellite data from various sources. This vignette concerns the cronus database creation.

Database Structure

The database takes the form of a 5-level structured directory. For a specific region, data can belong to one of three sectors: agricultural, environmental or satellite. Data are made available by a provider, usually an organization or a lab, which organizes the data in one or more products. Each product contains several variables of interest. You can see the materials covered in the package by calling the function print_tree().

  1. Parent Directory
  2. Region, (e.g. nebraska)
  3. Sector, (e.g. agricultural)
  4. Provider, (e.g. nass)
  5. Product, (e.g. cropmaps)
  6. Variable, (e.g. cdl)
library(cronus)
print_tree()
#> 
#> Cronus database structure 
#> 
#>  agricultural 
#>     |_ nass 
#>         |_ quickstats 
#>         |_ cropmaps 
#>     |_ bibliography 
#>         |_ parameters 
#> 
#>  environmental 
#>     |_ ornl 
#>         |_ daymet 
#> 
#>  satellite 
#>     |_ modis 
#>         |_ mod09ga 
#>         |_ myd09ga 
#>     |_ landsat 
#>         |_ landsat_tm_c1 
#>         |_ landsat_etm_c1 
#>         |_ landsat_8_c1 
#>     |_ sentinel 
#>         |_ s2msi2a 
#>         |_ sy_2_syn___

For more information on the nature of these data products, read vignette("Data").

The available products are in fact expressed as instances of S4 classes. This allows to create generic functions with different methods for each product, making it especially easy for new users to get familiar with the package. All class objects require three slots

  1. region, an object of class Region indicating the region of interest,
  2. date, an object of class Date indicating the time of interest and
  3. dir, an object of class character indicating the parent directory of the database.
 region <- Region(name = "nebraska", type = "us state", div = c(country = "United States", state = "Nebraska"))
 date <- as.Date("2020-07-15")
 dir <- getwd()

Now, it is straightforward to create an object of interest:

x <- new("Quickstats", region = region, date = date, dir = dir)
y <- new("Cropmaps",   region = region, date = date, dir = dir)
z <- new("Daymet",     region = region, date = date, dir = dir)

Package cronus offers a set of generic functions that work with these objects. First of all, we need to download the data, using the function download(). The following example shows how to download the NASS Quickstats progress variable, the NASS Cropmaps CDL variable and the ORNL Daymet tmin and tmax variables:

?download
download(x, variable = "progress")
download(y, variable = "cdl")
download(z, variable = c("tmin", "tmax"))

Note: All functions that may require more than a few seconds are equipped with a progress bar indicating the percentage completed, as well as the estimated time remaining.

You are now ready to read vignette("Download").
